question: Not the usual Swiss procedure, Mr. Bond, but you understand, a man in my position..
answer: Which is neutral, no doubt.

question: It wasn't easy, but I retrieved the money. No doubt Sir Robert will be pleased to see it again. In the current exchange rate, minus the fees, of course, and certain unforeseeable expenses. Here is the receipt...
answer: Perhaps later. My glasses.

question: It's all there.
answer: I didn't come for the money. The report you sold him was stolen from an MI-6 agent, who was killed for it.

question: I did not get the report from an MI-6 agent.
answer: Who did you get it from?

question: I am just a middle man. I am doing the honourable thing and returning the money to its rightful owner...
answer: And we know how difficult that can be for the Swiss.

question: Your last chance. Take the money.
answer: Your last chance. Give me the name.

question: Stripped of all your weaponry, you still threaten me?
answer: Perhaps you failed to take into account my...hidden assets. The name?

question: Have this checked, see what you can get off it.
answer: James. Brought me a souvenir from Geneva?

question: Thought you might want one of these.
answer: I gave up a long time ago. She's in with Sir Robert.

question: Construction's not exactly my line. Old friend? Who buys classified reports for three million pounds. Someone was watching over me in Geneva. A guardian angel with a laser sight. King.
answer: Security --

question: Stop! King!
answer: Beautiful, isn't it?

question: Yes.
answer: Today, of all days, the sun decides to shine.

question: Perhaps Sir Robert had a word with the Man Upstairs.
answer: A word? I'm sure by now he's engineered a hostile takeover.

question: You knew him well?
answer: He was my father.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: He died before he could complete his lifelong dream. I intend to finish it for him.

question: She's not a girl anymore. It's barely a scratch. The Dome broke my fall.
answer: Dislocated collar bone. If any more tendons snap... It won't just be two weeks out of action.

question: I need you to pass me fit now, Molly. It's just a scratch.
answer: James. It wouldn't really be...

question: Ethical? Can't we just skirt the issue?
answer: ...if you showed sufficient...willpower. Promised to slow down. Cut out running, jumping...shooting. All kinds of...

question: Strenuous activity?
answer: Then maybe I'd be... open to that.

question: Perhaps after this ... test?
The worm on the hook again. Scottish heavy metal, Q? And other uses, no doubt. That would make you..."R"?
answer: Bond. A government man. I'm afraid since you English got the boss killed we've been a little...jumpy.

question: I'd rather you didn't play with that.
answer: Nice.

question: Quite stunning.
answer: Sorry about all that, comrade. Old habits die hard. I am Head of Security. Davidov.

question: Sorry about all that, comrade. Old habits die hard. I am Head of Security. Davidov.
answer: ...they should have been in place two days ago. That is the target my father set.

question: Miss King...James Bond here to see you.
answer: Find me the research on the limestone deposits, go ahead and place these orders, and get the jeep ready. I will go to Ruan myself...

question: Miss King, I wouldn't recommend...
answer: I said, I will go. Would you excuse us, Davidov? I met you at my father's funeral.

question: I said, I will go. Would you excuse us, Davidov? I met you at my father's funeral.
answer: Yes.

question: I haven't been able to recall a single moment of that day...until now.
answer: Funerals aren't exactly memorable.

question: God no. All those horrible loved ones and relatives. I don't want to talk to those people. I just want to...talk to my father. I loved him. I'm not sure he knew that.
answer: Is that why you want to finish the pipeline?

question: Partially, yes. No, Gabor. We have a guest.
answer: Who is he?

question: My bodyguard. He follows me everywhere. He's decisive, vigilant. And he makes an excellent omelette.
answer: How long has he been with you?

question: Since the kidnapping. Why do you ask?
answer: Does this look familiar to you?

question: It's my father's pin. He wore it everyday of his life. Are you trying to break my heart? Or is it just your way with women?
answer: It's not the pin your father wore. It's an exact duplicate. Inside is a tiny electrical detonator. We have reason to believe the assassin had an inside accomplice, someone who worked at this company.

question: If you've come here to look after me, Mr. Bond, thank you, but no thank you. I have two bodyguards, I don't need a third...
answer: The killer doesn't want to see this pipeline continue, doesn't want to see you take over...

question: That's every man within a five mile radius. Including you. That's why you're here, isn't it? You think I can't do it. You think I'm going to screw up. Or get myself killed.
answer: I think running this pipeline would be a difficult job for anyone. Especially King's daughter.

question: You are wrong, Mr. Bond. In fact, I am the only person who can do it. My mother's people discovered oil here ninety years ago. The Bolsheviks slaughtered them for it. Some say oil is in my family's blood. I say our blood is in the oil. This is the very heart of the planet. Up here in the hills was Eden, literally. Look what the Russians did to it. Now we have a second chance and this time we'll do it right. When the other wells have all dried up, she'll still be pumping her lifeblood to the world. And this Will be one of the main arteries... Send the pipe around. Then my father was wrong. I have to check the upper lines. Gabor will drive you back.
answer: Always wanted to see the upper lines.

question: You don't take no for an answer, do you?
answer: No.

question: Alright then. Do you ski?
answer: I've been known to.

question: Just hold her steady. You wanted to see it. We're building from both ends. This is where they'll meet. Fifteen hundred miles from the Caspian to the Mediterranean.
answer: Head for that gully, I'll lure them into the trees! Should have stuck to snowboarding.

question: Are they gone? All of them?
answer: Hold on to me.

question: Oh my God...we're buried alive...
answer: We're alright.

question: I can't stay here.
answer: You're not going to.

question: No! It will cave in!
answer: It's the only way out...

question: I can't breathe, I can't breathe...
answer: Elektra, look at me, look in my eyes!

question: Are you alright?
answer: I can't stay.

question: I know. I need to ask you something. And I need you to tell me the truth. Who is it? Who is trying to kill me?
answer: I don't know. But I will find him.

question: After the kidnapping...I was afraid to go outside, to be alone, to be in a crowd, to do anything at all, until I realized... There's no point in living if you can't...feel alive. I can't huddle in the shadows. I can't let fear run my life. I won't. The way I acted, in the snow...you must think I'm a coward.
answer: I think you're one of the bravest people I've ever met.

question: What is it?
answer: ...you should rest.

question: James...
answer: I have to go.

question: Then take me with you.
answer: No. You'll be safe here.

question: I don't want to be safe!
answer: I have to go to work.

question: Now who's the coward?
answer: Valentin Zukovsky.

question: Valentin Zukovsky.
answer: BondJamesBond. What brings you here?

question: You, of course. I need some information.
answer: Bond, I'm a civilian. This is my place. Used to be the royal family's, now it's mine. I run my little business, I stay out of trouble...

question: Mafia warlords, Diplomats and spies, consortiums from every country in the world. A nice little rat's nest.
answer: Have some of the rat's nest caviar. From my own fishery. They buy my caviar, drink my champagne, lose to my House. Let me introduce you to a former colleague of mine at the KGB. Dmitri Palov, you may know him as...the Boa.

question: Boa. Have you had any therapy since Perestroika?
answer: Why am I suddenly worried I'm not carrying enough insurance? See? You're upsetting my customers. What do you want?

question: How does a terrorist like Renard supply his men with state-of-the-art Russian Army weapons?
answer: What? This is not possible.

question: If I remember my Cyrillic that says 101st airborne division.
answer: Where did you get this?

question: Off a high-powered Paraski that was trying to kill me.
answer: The Russian Army, they spend millions on flying skis, but they cannot afford to pay the soldiers. The men, they do what they have to do to feed their families. In this country, for the right price and a pack of cigarettes, you can get anything you want. That too. Everyone does what they can to survive.

question: How high up does this...arms dealing go?
answer: Bond. If someone wants you dead, it is Renard. Our government has nothing to gain by killing you.

question: But you would have something to gain by killing Robert King. And stopping his pipeline.
answer: Poor Bond. The cold war is over. What have you got left? Economic espionage. Murder in the boardroom. So dull.

question: Oh, you'd be surprised.
answer: We've kept your father's chair free.

question: Vodka martini.
answer: Two. Shaken not stirred. What the hell are you doing here?

question: Someone wants to kill me, I'd rather die looking him straight in the eye. What are you doing here? Looking for a woman a little more your type? How about that one?
answer: If this little show is for my benefit, I'll take you home right now.

question: Is this how you spend the money I pay you? And with the rest you hire fools who shoot like blind men?
answer: Bond...

question: Should be dead as well. Your failure today is astonishing. It is a disgrace. Do you know why the color is blue at the wick? Because that is where the flame is the hottest. The temperature is close to five hundred degrees.
answer: The plane...it's all been arranged...

question: Then you are completely unnecessary...
answer: I have the documents, the landing authorizations, the security passes...

question: Bond is suspicious. We are moving sooner, tonight. We understand each other?
answer: Yes...yes...

question: You knew when you first saw me. You knew it would be like this.
answer: Shush.

question: Poor shoulder. Looks painful...
answer: ...needs constant attention... Enough ice for one day. You never take this off?

question: Why do men always want to undress the one part of a woman's body she doesn't want to reveal?
answer: How did you survive?

question: I used my body on the guards. It gave me control. I got to a gun and I took my chance. I've never told anyone that. Do you ever stop, James? Do you ever think about...another kind of life?
answer: I can't afford to.

question: You new?
answer: Yes. Viktor Davidov, Miss...?

question: Doctor. Jones. Christmas Jones. No jokes, I've heard them all.
answer: Don't know any doctor jokes.

question: What happened to Len Tashka?
answer: Couldn't make it. Splitting headache.

question: The soldiers may give you a hard time. Whatever. If we weren't around, they'd have their whole nuclear arsenal lying by the roadsides, rotting in the sun.
answer: Will I need protection?

question: There's no radiation danger down there. Where is this stockpile going?
answer: To the nuclear facility at Penza 19. Corporal?

question: To the nuclear facility at Penza 19. Corporal?
answer: I see my friend Davidov ran into some difficulty.

question: Indeed. Don't come any closer.
answer: Go ahead. Shoot. My men will still steal the bomb, and the shot will bring them directly to you.

question: Who's paying you to destroy the pipeline?
answer: To die by a man who can't even grasp what he's caught up in...

question: Revenge isn't so hard to fathom. What's clever is getting someone else to pay for it.
answer: Not many people in this world have that kind of fortune.

question: Who is it?
answer: You think I fear death? I welcome it. I get on my knees and pray for it. You, on the other hand, you have something to live for, no? She's beautiful isn't she? You should have seen her before. Flawless, and still so innocent, not such a whore in bed...

question: You will never touch her. You will never get near her.
answer: Have you forgotten who saved your life in Geneva?

question: Consider me ungrateful.
answer: It's I who should thank you -- for taking that money back to MI-6. So distressing for M. An explosion inside her lair.

question: She'll get over it.
answer: You even brought the plane for us. We really couldn't have done it without you. A man tires of being executed. But then again...There is no point in living if you can't...feel alive.

question: Close the door! Close the door! Shame you had to spot I wasn't the real thing.
answer: So who are you?

question: Bond -- James Bond.
answer: They won't get far. Every warhead has a locator card. A Miratom device. Emits a high-pitched signal on Russian emergency frequencies. We can track the bomb.

question: I'm sorry. I would never call you except...Bond's disappeared. He...he left my villa, some time in the middle of the night and... My head of security has been found near a local airstrip, murdered... Could...could you come? I just can't help thinking...I'm next. Gabor...? James!
answer: You look surprised.

question: What's wrong with you? Are you crazy?
answer: A little. Does it matter? After all, what's the point of living if you can't feel alive? Isn't that right, Elektra? Isn't that your motto?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Or did you steal it from your old friend Renard?

question: ...what?
answer: We had a run-in, he and I. He knew about us, he knew about my shoulder, he knew exactly where to hurt me...

question: Are you saying...Renard is the man who's trying to kill me?
answer: You can drop the act, it's over.

question: I don't know what you're talking about!
answer: I think you do. At MI-6 we call it Stockholm Syndrome. It's common in kidnappings. A young impressionable victim. Sheltered, sexually inexperienced. A powerful kidnapper skilled in torture, in manipulation. Something snaps in the victim's mind. The captive falls in love with her captor.

question: How dare you! How dare you! That animal!? That monster!? He disgusts me! You disgust me! So he knew where to hurt you, is that it? You had a sling on your arm at the funeral! I didn't have to sleep with you to find that out.
answer: He used your exact words.

question: You knew. You knew all the time, that he was out there, that he was coming for me, and you lied. You used me, you used me as bait. You made love to me -- what, to pass the time as you waited for him to strike? He's struck again. Five men are dead at the pipeline.
answer: I'm coming with you.

question: You do what you have to do, but I've called in M. She's en route from London even now.
answer: They hit about 90 minutes ago. There's a scientist here from the International Decommissioning Agency, Dr. Jones. She has ten crews combing the area.

question: Faster! Get our speed up!
answer: Tactical fission device. Low yield. The plutonium is missing. They've taken the core!

question: Then it's no longer a bomb?
answer: It's a bomb alright. We're still dead if the trigger charge goes off...

question: Let it blow.
answer: But we can stop it.

question: What the hell were you doing? You nearly killed us!
answer: I did kill us. She thinks we're dead. And she thinks she got away with it.

question: What the hell are you talking about?
answer: It's part of some plan. She dresses it up like a terrorist attack. The explosion covers up the theft of the plutonium.

question: Who's she?
answer: Elektra King.

question: Elektra King? Are you insane? This is her pipeline.
answer: Makes her look even more innocent.

question: What would she want with weapons grade plutonium?
answer: I was hoping you could tell me.

question: Tanner to 007, do you read?
answer: Loud and clear. I have to speak to M.

question: She's gone.
answer: What?

question: You're hurting me. Brought me something?
answer: Go on. It's safe. Touch your destiny.

question: Warm.
answer: Is it?

question: I've brought something for you as well. Just as I promised.
answer: My executioner.

question: Your people? Your people will leave you here to rot just like you left me. You and my father. He didn't think my life was worth the chump change he spent on a day at the stock market. Is nothing. His kingdom he stole from my mother. The kingdom I will rightly take back.
answer: No. I'm afraid it is what you did. When I took her she was...promise itself. So clever, so vibrant, so...full of life force. And you left her there, at the mercy of a man like me. You ruined her. For what? To get to me? She is worth fifty of me. No. I wanted you. I wanted you for myself. Since you sent your man to kill me, I have been watching time tick slowly away, marching inevitably toward my own death. Watch these hands, M. At noon tomorrow, your time is up. And I guarantee you...I will not miss. You will die. Along with everyone in this city and the future of the West.

question: What are doing, Bond? Trying to impress this innocent thing?
answer: She's no innocent. This is my nuclear consultant.

question: Ah, I see. A purely...plutonic relationship. Really Bond, couldn't you find a nice Russian scientist with hair growing out of his ears?
answer: What's your business with Elektra King?

question: I thought you were the one in her business.
answer: She dropped a million and half dollars to the House -- your House. And you didn't even bat an eyelid. She was paying you off. What for?

question: As ever you are the spy who has to see a plot wherever he looks. That is 5,000 dollars of Beluga ruined!
answer: You are out of your league. She's working with Renard.

question: Tell us what you know, Zukovsky. Tell us, before its too late. Now...where were we?
answer: A rope!

question: No. The truth! She thought I was dead -- those blades were meant for you. What do you know that she would kill you for?
answer: I don't know what you're talking -- Help me, don't let me drown.

question: You're in this thing up to your neck.
answer: Alright, alright! Sometimes I smuggle machinery for her. Russian stuff.

question: And the payoff on the tables?
answer: A special job. A...a...a submarine.

question: To haul some cargo. My nephew, he is Captain of a sub in the Black Sea Fleet.
answer: Where's the sub going?!

question: No! Get me out!
answer: This is too big for even you. Where is it?

question: So beautiful. So smooth, so warm.
answer: How would you know?

question: Why are you like this? Because Bond is dead? It's what you wanted.
answer: Of course...

question: He was a...good lover?
answer: What do you think?

question: Nothing.
answer: What about this?

question: Nothing.
answer: But surely... ...You can feel this? Remember ... pleasure?

question: The right kind of explosion in the right spot -- it would block the Bosphorus, cut off the Black Sea.
answer: But why? Eight million people would die, the land irradiated for a hundred years. A cloud of radiation the size of Europe...

question: Because an explosion like that would kill all the other pipelines. There would be only one way to get the oil out of the Caspian and pump it to the world...
answer: The King pipeline.

question: Take them up and throw them in the sea. We'll be underway in two hours. Use that time to re-familiarize yourselves with your stations. Then ponder how rich you'll be. The re-breathers for the escape are already on board.
answer: Now you know how it feels. To be locked away, to wonder if they're coming for you, if anyone will ever come for you. Who? Bond? Bond is dead. Somehow, I find that strangely ...disappointing. Time for you to die.

question: The reactor is secured. This is the end.
answer: No. It is the beginning. The world will never be the same.

question: If I don't get to the Boa before he gets to Maiden's Tower, M is dead.
answer: James Bond and his amazing resurrection. If only you'd kept away, we might have met again in a few years, become lovers once more. Take her to Renard. Pretty thing. You had her too? I could have given you the world.

question: Not interested.
answer: They were digging near here and they found some very pretty vases. They also found this... I think we ignore the old ways at our peril, don't you?

question: Where's M?
answer: Soon she'll be everywhere.

question: All this, because you fell for Renard?
answer: Five more turns and your neck will break. Since I was a child, I've always had a power over men. When I realized my father wouldn't rescue me from the kidnappers, I knew I had to form a new alliance.

question: You turned Renard.
answer: Just like you...only you were even easier. I told him he had to hurt me, he had to make it look real. When he refused I told him I would do it myself.

question: So you killed your father.
answer: He killed me! He killed me the day he refused to pay my ransom.

question: Was this all about the oil?
answer: It is my oil! Mine and my family's! It runs in my veins, thicker than blood. I'm going to redraw the map. And when I am through the whole world will know my name, my grandfather's name, the glory of my people.

question: No-one will believe this melt-down was an accident.
answer: They will believe. They will all believe. You understand? Nobody can resist me. Know what happens when a man is strangled?

question: Elektra, it's not too late. Eight million people needn't die.
answer: You should have killed me when you had the chance. But you couldn't. Not me. A woman you've loved.

question: You meant ... nothing ... to me. One... last... screw?
answer: Oh James.

question: We go down to the torpedo bay.
answer: Open the tanks.

question: Tanks open.
answer: Bond... Bond! You have decided to join me on this historic voyage. Welcome to my nuclear family.

question: You're really going to commit suicide for her?
answer: In case you've forgotten. I'm dead already.

question: Haven't you heard the news? So is she.
answer: You will die for this.

question: The cover is off the reactor.
answer: He's sealed himself in.

question: He's going to insert the plutonium. Do you know what you're doing?
answer: Like riding a bike.

question: What kind of bikes did you ride?
answer: Just wanted to put him on edge...
